sentence.source: Astrid De Wit, Frank Brisard (2014), Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages. Vol. 29:1. pp. 1–48. Example 1
sentence.text: Di a karta fadon, dan mi e si en.
sentence.gloss: When the card fell, then I saw his feet.

sentence.source: Astrid De Wit, Frank Brisard (2014), Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages. Vol. 29:1. pp. 1–48. Example 2
sentence.text: Ala sma sabi now pe den e kari.
sentence.gloss: All people now know the place they call Micromarkt.

sentence.source: Astrid De Wit, Frank Brisard (2014), Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages. Vol. 29:1. pp. 1–48. Example 3
sentence.text: Nownow yu e teki en kba nownow?
sentence.gloss: Are you already taping right now?

sentence.source: Astrid De Wit, Frank Brisard (2014), Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages. Vol. 29:1. pp. 1–48. Example 4
sentence.text: A yuru te yu kon baka mi o kba skrifi a brifi disi.
sentence.gloss: By the time when you come back, I will/should have finished writing this letter.

sentence.source: Astrid De Wit, Frank Brisard (2014), Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages. Vol. 29:1. pp. 1–48. Example 4
sentence.text: A yuru te yu kon baka mi sa kba skrifi a brifi disi.
sentence.gloss: By the time when you come back, I will/should have finished writing this letter.

sentence.source: Astrid De Wit, Frank Brisard (2014), Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages. Vol. 29:1. pp. 1–48. Example 5
sentence.text: Want na tu leisi mi nanga a man meki afspraak kaba, a man no kon.
sentence.gloss: Because it is already twice that me and the man made an appointment, and the man didn’t come.

sentence.source: Astrid De Wit, Frank Brisard (2014), Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages. Vol. 29:1. pp. 1–48. Example 6
sentence.text: Ma efu mi ben sori en taki mi ben bron, dan a bo du wan fasi nanga mi.
sentence.gloss: But if I had shown him that I was burned, then he would have done something for me.

sentence.source: Astrid De Wit, Frank Brisard (2014), Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages. Vol. 29:1. pp. 1–48. Example 7
sentence.text: Dan omeni yari a ben abi?
sentence.gloss: So how old was he?

sentence.source: Astrid De Wit, Frank Brisard (2014), Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages. Vol. 29:1. pp. 1–48. Example 9
sentence.text: Nownow yu e teki en kba nownow?
sentence.gloss: Are you already taping right now?’

sentence.source: Astrid De Wit, Frank Brisard (2014), Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages. Vol. 29:1. pp. 1–48. Example 10
sentence.text: Alexi teki en spikri, a go na bakadyari.
sentence.gloss: Alexi took his mirror and went into the backyard.

sentence.source: Astrid De Wit, Frank Brisard (2014), Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages. Vol. 29:1. pp. 1–48. Example 11
sentence.text: Den pikin wani prey.
sentence.gloss: The children want to play

sentence.source: Astrid De Wit, Frank Brisard (2014), Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages. Vol. 29:1. pp. 1–48. Example 12
sentence.attribution: taken from Seuren 1981, cited in Winford 2000:427
sentence.text: Safrisafri mi e sabi den pasi kba.
sentence.gloss: Slowly I am already getting to know the roads.

sentence.source: Astrid De Wit, Frank Brisard (2014), Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages. Vol. 29:1. pp. 1–48. Example 13
sentence.text: Fosten, i no ben e abi kasi, ben e abi falis.
sentence.gloss: Previously, one wouldn’t have a wardrobe, one would have a piece of luggage.

sentence.source: Astrid De Wit, Frank Brisard (2014), Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages. Vol. 29:1. pp. 1–48. Example 14
sentence.text: San mi wani taki over a brifi: ...
sentence.gloss: What I want to say about the letter: ...

sentence.source: Astrid De Wit, Frank Brisard (2014), Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages. Vol. 29:1. pp. 1–48. Example 15
sentence.text: Dan Alexi lon kon.
sentence.gloss: Then Alexi came running.

sentence.source: Astrid De Wit, Frank Brisard (2014), Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages. Vol. 29:1. pp. 1–48. Example 15
sentence.text: Alexi taki: ‘Fa a waka?’
sentence.gloss: Alexi said: ‘What’s going on?’

sentence.source: Astrid De Wit, Frank Brisard (2014), Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages. Vol. 29:1. pp. 1–48. Example 15
sentence.text: A taki: ‘Luku dya, luku dya, luku dya!’
sentence.gloss: She said: ‘Look here, look here, look here!’.

sentence.source: Astrid De Wit, Frank Brisard (2014), Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages. Vol. 29:1. pp. 1–48. Example 16
sentence.text: Mi brada e denki a watra sa kowru.
sentence.gloss: My brother thinks the water is cold (but he is wrong).

sentence.source: Astrid De Wit, Frank Brisard (2014), Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages. Vol. 29:1. pp. 1–48. Example 16
sentence.text: Mi brada denki a watra sa kowru.
sentence.gloss: My brother thinks the water is cold (but he is wrong).

sentence.source: Astrid De Wit, Frank Brisard (2014), Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages. Vol. 29:1. pp. 1–48. Example 17
sentence.text: Mi brada taki a watra kowru.
sentence.gloss: My brother says (right now) that the water is cold.

sentence.source: Astrid De Wit, Frank Brisard (2014), Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages. Vol. 29:1. pp. 1–48. Example 18
sentence.text: Yu miti mi brada kba?
sentence.gloss: Have you met my brother yet?

sentence.source: Astrid De Wit, Frank Brisard (2014), Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages. Vol. 29:1. pp. 1–48. Example 19
sentence.text: Ay, a leysi a buku disi kba.
sentence.gloss: Yes, he has already read this book.

sentence.source: Astrid De Wit, Frank Brisard (2014), Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages. Vol. 29:1. pp. 1–48. Example 20
sentence.text: En vanaf a ten fu Bruma, mi volg den alamala op de voet.
sentence.gloss: And since the time of Bruma, I have been following them all closely.

sentence.source: Astrid De Wit, Frank Brisard (2014), Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages. Vol. 29:1. pp. 1–48. Example 21
sentence.text: A tori di mi e go ferteri now na wan tori di psa langa, langa yari kba.
sentence.gloss: The story that I am now going to tell is a story that happened many, many years ago.

sentence.source: Astrid De Wit, Frank Brisard (2014), Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages. Vol. 29:1. pp. 1–48. Example 21
sentence.text: Ma dan now, wan neti leki fa mi taki, dan den man de na ini a faya fu a prei.
sentence.gloss: But now one night, like I said, the men are/were in the thick of the game.

sentence.source: Astrid De Wit, Frank Brisard (2014), Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages. Vol. 29:1. pp. 1–48. Example 21
sentence.text: Dan a doro klop.
sentence.gloss: Then there is/was a knock at the door.

sentence.source: Astrid De Wit, Frank Brisard (2014), Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages. Vol. 29:1. pp. 1–48. Example 21
sentence.text: Wan fu den go luku, dan den si wan man tnapu.
sentence.gloss: One of them goes/went to look, then they see/saw a man standing there.

sentence.source: Astrid De Wit, Frank Brisard (2014), Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages. Vol. 29:1. pp. 1–48. Example 21
sentence.text: Dan a man taki: ‘Yere, mi yere un de wan club dyaso e prei carta.
sentence.gloss: The man says/said: ‘Listen, I hear(d) you have a club here for playing cards

sentence.source: Astrid De Wit, Frank Brisard (2014), Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages. Vol. 29:1. pp. 1–48. Example 21
sentence.text: Mi kan prei tu?
sentence.gloss: Can I play too?

sentence.source: Astrid De Wit, Frank Brisard (2014), Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages. Vol. 29:1. pp. 1–48. Example 21
sentence.text: Den taki: ‘Ai’.
sentence.gloss: They say/said: ‘Yes’.

sentence.source: Astrid De Wit, Frank Brisard (2014), Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages. Vol. 29:1. pp. 1–48. Example 21
sentence.text: A man kon na ini ...
sentence.gloss: The man comes/came inside ...

sentence.source: Astrid De Wit, Frank Brisard (2014), Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages. Vol. 29:1. pp. 1–48. Example 21
sentence.text: Den luku makandra, bikasi te wan vreemde sma e kon prei den prei fufuru nanga en.
sentence.gloss: They [the men] look/looked at each other, because whenever a stranger comes/came to play they cheat/cheated him.

sentence.source: Astrid De Wit, Frank Brisard (2014), Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages. Vol. 29:1. pp. 1–48. Example 21
sentence.text: Dan den sabi taki den e go feni wan man fu den nyan sensi na en skin.
sentence.gloss: Then they know/knew they are/were going to find a man from whom they could get money.

sentence.source: Astrid De Wit, Frank Brisard (2014), Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages. Vol. 29:1. pp. 1–48. Example 22
sentence.text: A ten di den wroko a wroko, a man taki: ‘Ai, no.’
sentence.gloss: At the time when they have/had done the job, the men say/said: ‘Yes, no.’

sentence.source: Astrid De Wit, Frank Brisard (2014), Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages. Vol. 29:1. pp. 1–48. Example 22
sentence.text: Dan a bun.
sentence.gloss: Then it’s good.

sentence.source: Astrid De Wit, Frank Brisard (2014), Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages. Vol. 29:1. pp. 1–48. Example 23
sentence.text: Mi go tide mi e suku fu bai wan batra oli.
sentence.gloss: I went looking today for a bottle of oil to buy. Forty guilder did the man ask for one liter of oil.

sentence.source: Astrid De Wit, Frank Brisard (2014), Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages. Vol. 29:1. pp. 1–48. Example 24
sentence.text: Ma dan now, wan neti leki fa mi taki, dan den man de na ini a faya fu a prei.
sentence.gloss: But now one night, like I said, the men are/were in the thick of the game.

sentence.source: Astrid De Wit, Frank Brisard (2014), Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages. Vol. 29:1. pp. 1–48. Example 25
sentence.text: A koso wan leysi.
sentence.gloss: He coughed once.

sentence.source: Astrid De Wit, Frank Brisard (2014), Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages. Vol. 29:1. pp. 1–48. Example 26
sentence.text: Efu yu wani yu e teki en, efu yu no wani yu no e teki en.
sentence.gloss: If you want to [pay a lot], you’re taking it; if you don’t want to [pay a lot], you’re not taking it.

sentence.source: Astrid De Wit, Frank Brisard (2014), Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages. Vol. 29:1. pp. 1–48. Example 27
sentence.text: Dus ef’ a sma denki f’ a de, a sma kan tan gewoon nanga en pikin te ala sani waka a sma bun.
sentence.gloss: Thus, if the person considers how it is, the person can just keep her child, until everything goes well for the person.

sentence.source: Astrid De Wit, Frank Brisard (2014), Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages. Vol. 29:1. pp. 1–48. Example 28
sentence.text: Efu mi teki a wroko disi a mi tapu, a kan koste mi mi libi.
sentence.gloss: If I take on this job, it can cost me my life.

sentence.source: Astrid De Wit, Frank Brisard (2014), Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages. Vol. 29:1. pp. 1–48. Example 33
sentence.text: Mi no e si wan boto, ma mi e si tu boto.
sentence.gloss: I don’t see one boat, but I see two boats.

sentence.source: Astrid De Wit, Frank Brisard (2014), Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages. Vol. 29:1. pp. 1–48. Example 34
sentence.text: Dati wani taki, pe den sma e go go prei karta.
sentence.gloss: That is, that’s where the people go to play cards.

sentence.source: Astrid De Wit, Frank Brisard (2014), Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages. Vol. 29:1. pp. 1–48. Example 35
sentence.text: A kownu dede.
sentence.gloss: The king died.

sentence.source: Astrid De Wit, Frank Brisard (2014), Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages. Vol. 29:1. pp. 1–48. Example 36
sentence.text: Suma ben bow a oso disi?
sentence.gloss: Who built his house?

sentence.source: Astrid De Wit, Frank Brisard (2014), Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages. Vol. 29:1. pp. 1–48. Example 37
sentence.text: Efu mi no ben abi yu, dan fa mi ben sa bigin dan?
sentence.gloss: If I didn’t have you, then how would I begin?
